title: Making Renewable, Infinitely Recyclable Plastics Using Bacteria – Berkeley Lab News Center - Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (.gov)
summary: Researchers have engineered E. coli to convert plant sugars into poly(diketoenamine) (PDK), a recyclable plastic that can replace petrochemical-derived plastics. This bio-based process shows potential for being both environmentally friendly and cost-effective in comparison to traditional plastics. The development allows for multiple applications in various industries, including automotive, and aims to address the growing plastic waste problem by creating materials that are biorenewable and circular. Future improvements in production could lead to cheaper bio-based PDKs that emit less CO2 than those produced with fossil fuels.
